It’s a separate unit that exchanges stale air from inside with fresh air from outside and feeds in into the cold air return.

Install cost me about $4500.

ERV/HRVs exchange air without the outdoors without losing the heat energy (in cold areas) or without adding humidity (in warm areas).

A window would be 0% energy efficient at exchanging air, where as this is about 75% efficient.
Mostly I use an Aranet4, which is great and super accurate.

I’ve put a lot of time and money and effort into insulating my house, but as a result the air quality hasn’t been the best.

Installed an air-to-air exchanger (ERV) today and the Co2 levels dropped like a rock and have sat at 400ppm.

Hooray for good ventilation.

why do clients need to be able to pull down a list of every like a user has ever made? the data model attaches likes to a tweet, that list isn’t used for anything important besides being a list.

if I like some random piece of pornography, there is basically nobody keeping track if not for that list.

you can also make likes only visible to the poster, which solves that problem entirely.
design is all about meeting people’s expectations, and the “like list” missed that by a mile
making the like list visible only to the original poster was my personal preferred compromise, but that ship sailed long ago.

it is more or less technically impossible for an entity to ingest every extant tweet and find out who liked it, so without that list it’s basically undiscoverable.

(you could also do things like making likes visible only to the poster)

a “like” is a considerably more passive action than a retweet or reply, people simply don’t understand that clicking like on a piece of pornography (or whatever) would end up in an eternal public list for people to trawl through.
it is not a just world

It works really well on Reddit, but that's because the base unit on Reddit is "subreddit" and not "person."

How you manage that in a one-to-many social graph seems really difficult, short of some mechanism to tell people those community-limited posts exist (which has its own safety problems).

One thing that I've always wanted — and I'm not 100% sure it's a great idea, to be clear — is being able to subscribe to a centralized mute / blocklist.

There have been webextensions to do the same on Twitter, but being able to subscribe to a hosted blocklist by someone I trust could be a thing.

I did the security work on Twitter Communities, which was more-or-less exactly that.

The trick is that communities need to be made first class citizens with high discoverability, otherwise, like Twitter Communities, it kind of becomes a bad Discord and your posts wither away.
